results.headline: More Yang Than Yin? Better Fix Your Life Force
results.summary_short: “Man of Tai Chi,” Keanu Reeves’s directorial debut, is all about the fight.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Man of Tai Chi

results.headline: The Philanderer Reconsiders
results.summary_short: In “A Perfect Man,” Liev Schreiber plays an architect who, after his affairs lead his wife to leave him, begins to rethink his behavior.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Perfect Man

results.headline: In Sin City, Men Will, Predictably, Be Boys
results.summary_short: “Last Vegas” features four strong actors and a plot that viewers can see coming.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Vegas

results.headline: The Kids Are Not Happy About Dad’s New Friend
results.summary_short: Sandra Nettelbeck’s “Last Love” stars Michael Caine as a cantankerous widower whose two children are concerned about his relationship with a young Parisian.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Love

results.headline: America, That Very Tough Neighborhood
results.summary_short: “Immigrant,” a tale of a Russian family’s move in the 1970s, shows the United States as anything but welcoming.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Immigrant

results.headline: Rethinking the Main Course
results.summary_short: In “Free Birds,” Woody Harrelson and Owen Wilson provide the voices for two turkeys who travel back in time to alter the first Thanksgiving.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free Birds

results.display_title: Following the Ninth: In the Footsteps of Beethoven's Final Symphony
results.headline: The Ode Heard Round the World
results.summary_short: “Following the Ninth,” a documentary, explores the legacy of Beethoven’s final symphony.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Following the Ninth: In the Footsteps of Beethoven's Final Symphony

results.headline: And a Child Shall Lead Them Into Space Battle
results.summary_short: “Ender’s Game” imagines a future in which youngsters are trained as warriors from an early age to fight Earth’s enemies, the large, insectlike Formics.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ender's Game

results.headline: A Way of Life, and Its Slow Death
results.summary_short: “Behind the Blue Veil” chronicles the Tuareg people of Mali and the threats to their culture.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Behind the Blue Veil

results.headline: Old Hatreds Just Won’t Stay Buried
results.summary_short: Wladyslaw Pasikowski’s “Aftermath” is a Holocaust-related story set in the modern-day in a Polish town.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aftermath

results.headline: Manly? Yes, in That Present-Day British Way
results.summary_short: A Hugh Grant wannabe (Domhnall Gleeson) and his father (Bill Nighy) indulge the supernatural talent shared by the men in their family.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of About Time

results.headline: No Lights, No Camera, No Action
results.summary_short: “Golden Slumbers” — a film about Cambodian cinema, whose history was wiped clean by the Khmer Rouge — gleans traces of the erased past through interviews.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Golden Slumbers

results.headline: Yearning for Tenderness, and More, in a Vale of Cynicism
results.summary_short: “In the Name Of,” directed by Malgoska Szumowska, focuses on a Polish priest transferred to the countryside who struggles with his longing for a local teenager.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Name of

results.headline: Filmmaker Chronicles His Battle With Illness
results.summary_short: The director Jason DaSilva records his daily battle with a degenerative disease in “When I Walk.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When I Walk

results.headline: Brave Optimism of Tahrir Square Meets Other Fierce Forces
results.summary_short: “The Square,” Jehane Noujaim’s new documentary, makes the Egyptian uprising and the political fallout of this summer feel close and personal.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Square

results.headline: Wildlife Is Tame; Not the Humans
results.summary_short: Ridley Scott and Cormac McCarthy team up for “The Counselor,” a tale of a corrupt, high-flying lawyer dealing with a drug cartel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Counselor

results.headline: The Man Beneath the Hairspray
results.summary_short: Divine, a muse to John Waters and the star in many of his studies in bad taste, is the subject of the film “I am Divine,” directed by Jeffrey Schwarz.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Am Divine

results.headline: For a While, Her Life Is Yours
results.summary_short: Abdellatif Kechiche’s “Blue Is the Warmest Color” is a feverish, generous, exhausting love story that chronicles a young woman’s wrenching and blissful attachment to another woman.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blue is the Warmest Color

results.headline: Tripping All the Way to the Gates of Hell
results.summary_short: In Jason Banker’s “Toad Road,” two young people high on drugs check out a local legend and its supposedly sinister secrets.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Toad Road

results.headline: Finding Love in a Cruel Time
results.summary_short: In “The Pin,” Naomi Jaye tells a tale of two young Eastern Europeans hiding in a barn during World War II and creates a mood of unadulterated romance.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pin
